subsection.title: The Zero-Factor Principle
subsection.p: In Lesson we applied the Zero-Factor Principle to solve quadratic equations of the form ax^2+bx+c=0. For reference, here is the statement of the Zero-Factor Principle.

assemblage.title: Zero-Factor Principle
assemblage.p: If the product of two numbers is zero, then one (or both) of the numbers must be zero. Using symbols, \text{If}~AB=0,~\text{then either} ~A=0~\text{or}~B=0.

subsection.p: In order to solve more general quadratic equations, of the form ax^2+bx+c=0 we will need to factor quadratic trinomials. Here is an example of how we can use the principle to solve a quadratic equation.

ol.label: a
ol.li: We use the FOIL method to apply the distributive law to the product. graphic

From part (a) we see that ~x^2+x-20 can also be written in factored form as ~(x+5)(x-4). Thus, the equation ~x^2+x-20 is equivalent to (x+5)(x-4)=0 We can apply the Zero-Factor Principle to this equation: If the product is zero, then one of the factors must be zero. Thus, either x+5=0~~~~\text{or}~~~~x-4=0 This means that either x=-5 or x=4. These are the solutions of the equation, as we verify below. \blert{\text{Check:}}~~\amp \text{Substitute each value into the original equation.} \amp x=\alert{-5}:~~~~~~ (\alert{-5})^2+(\alert{-5})-20=25-5-20=0 \amp x=\alert{4}: ~~~~~~~~~~ (\alert{4})^2+(\alert{4})-20=25-5-20=0

statement.p: Why can't we solve the equation ~x^2+x-20=0 in by extraction of roots?

answer.p: Because of the linear term, x.

subsection.title: Factoring Quadratic Trinomials
subsection.p: In Lesson we learned to factor quadratic expressions of the form ax^2+bx. Now we consider quadratic trinomials of the form x^2+bx+c. Many of these can be factored into the product of two binomials. For example, x^2+7x+12=(x+3)(x+4)

How can we come up with the factors of the quadratic trinomial? Let's recall how the product is obtained. We apply the distributive law and multiply each term of the first binomial by each term of the second binomial. We use the word "FOIL" to label the four terms of the product: First, Outside, Inside, and Last.

statement.p: Where does the constant term of the trinomial appear in the product box?
Where does the linear term appear?

answer.p: In the upper left and lower right boxes.

subsection.p: We make several observations about this product.

ol.li: The quadratic term, x^2, comes from the product of the First terms in each binomial.
The constant term, 12, is the product of the Last terms.
The middle term, 7x, is the sum of two terms, the product of the Inside terms and the product of the Outside terms.

subsection.p: We can see that the first term of each factor must be x, so we only need to fill in the blanks below with the correct numbers: x^2+7x+12=(x+)(x+) If the two numbers are p and q, then (x+p)(x+q)\amp =x^2+qx+px+pq \amp x^2 + (\blert{p+q})x + \blert{pq} We see that the constant term of the trinomial is the product pq, and the linear term of the trinomial has as coefficient the sum p+q.

Thus, to factor x^2+7x+12, we look for two integers p and q whose sum is 7 and whose product is 12. With a little trial and error, we discover that the two integers are 3 and 4. So the factored form is x^2+7x+12=(x+3)(x+4)

assemblage.title: To Factor a Quadratic Trinomial
assemblage.p: To factor x^2+bx+c, we look for two numbers p and q so that \blert{pq=c}~~~~\text{and}~~~~\blert{p+q=b}

solution.p: We see that 5 \cdot 8 = 40 and 5+8=13, so the correct factorization is a^2+13a+40=(a+5)(a+8) We can also write the factored form as (a+8)(a+5); the order of the factors does not matter. Aside from rearranging the factors, there is only one correct factorization for these quadratic trinomials.

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: In the Activities we'll see how to factor trinomials with negative coefficients. Here are the results.

assemblage.title: Sign Patterns for Factoring Quadratic Trinomials
assemblage.p:
Assume that b,~c,~p, and q are positive integers.
x^2+bx+c=(x+p)(x+q)
If all the coefficients of the trinomial are positive, then both p and q are positive.
x^2-bx+c=(x-p)(x-q)
If the linear term of the trinomial is negative and the other two terms positive, then p and q are both negative.
x^2 \pm bx+c=(x+p)(x-q)
If the constant term of the trinomial is negative, then p and q have opposite signs.

solution.p: We look for two integers p and q for which pq=-18 and p+q=3. Because pq is negative, p and q must have opposite signs. Because p+q is positive, the choices are -1~\text{and}~18,~~~~-2~\text{and}~9,~~~~\text{or}~~~~-3~\text{and}~6 Because -3+6=3, the correct factorization is x^2+3x-18=(x-3)(x+6) You can check the factorization by multiplying the two binomials to see that their product is in fact ~x^2+3x-18.

subsection.title: Solving a Quadratic Equation
subsection.p: Now we can use factoring to solve a quadratic equation.

warning.p: Before factoring and applying the Zero-Factor Principle, we must write the equation in standard form, so that one side of the equation is zero. Thus, it would not be useful to write x(x+3)=18 We cannot apply the Zero-Factor principle to this equation.

statement.p: Why can't we solve the equation x(x+3)=18 by setting each factor equal to 18?

answer.p: Just because a product equals 18 does not mean that one of its factors equals 18.

subsection.p: Here is our method for solving a quadratic equation by factoring.

assemblage.title: To Solve a Quadratic Equation by Factoring

ol.li: Write the equation in standard form, ax^2+bx+c=0~~~~~~(a \not= 0)
Factor the left side of the equation.
Apply the Zero-Factor Principle; that is, set each factor equal to zero.
Solve each equation to obtain two solutions.

solution.p: You may notice that each term of this equation is twice the corresponding term of the equation in . We can factor out a common factor of 2 from the left side of the standard form of this equation. 2x^2+6x-36 \amp =0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Factor out 2 from the left side.}} 2(x^2+3x-18) \amp = 0 Then we can divide both sides of the equation by 2. \dfrac{2(x^2+3x-18)}{\blert{2}} \amp = \dfrac{0}{\blert{2}} x^2+3x-18 \amp = 0 This new equation is the same as the equation in . Thus, the solutions are the same as the solutions in , namely, -6 and 3.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Multiplying the equation in by a factor of 2 does not affect the solutions of the equation. We can divide both sides of a quadratic (or any) equation by a nonzero constant factor while solving.

subsection.title: Application
subsection.p: Delbert is standing at the edge of a 240-foot cliff. He throws his algebra book upwards off the cliff with a velocity of 32 feet per second. The height of his book above the ground (at the base of the cliff) after t seconds is given by the formula h=-16t^2+32t+240 where h is in feet. The figure below shows a graph of the equation.

From the graph, we see that it takes the book 5 seconds to reach the ground. Because h=0 when the book reaches the ground, 5 is one of the solutions of the quadratic equation 0=-16t^2+32t+240 Can we solve this equation algebraically, without using a graph?

statement.p: The equation h=-16t^2+32t+240 gives the height of a book above the ground t seconds after being thrown off a cliff. How long will it take the book to reach the ground?

solution.p: We set h=0 to obtain the equation -16t^2+32t+240=0 It is easier to factor if the coefficient of t^2 is positive, so we factor out -16. -16(t^2-2t-15) \amp =0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Divide both sides by}~-16.} t^2-2t-15 \amp = 0 Now we are ready to factor the left side of the equation. You can verify that the factorization is (t+3)(t-5)=0 Applying the Zero-Factor Principle yields t+3=0 ~~~~~~ t-5 \amp =0 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Solve each equation.}} t=-3 ~~~~~~ t \amp = 5 The solutions are -3 and 5. Because a negative time does not make sense for this problem, we discard that solution. The book takes 5 seconds to reach the ground.

statement.p: In , why did we set h=0?

answer.p: When the book reaches the ground, its height is zero.

subsubsection.title: Activity 1: Factoring a Quadratic Trinomial
subsubsection.p: \blert{\text{CASE 1}}~~~ Positive coefficients: ~x^2+bx+c
If all the coefficients in the quadratic trinomial are positive, then p and q are also positive.
\blert{\text{Example 1}}~~~Factor ~t^2+9t+18~ as a product of two binomials t^2+9t+18 = (~~+~~)~(~~+~~)
\blert{\text{Step 1}}~~~The product of the First terms must be t^2, so we place t's in the First spots. t^2+9t+18 = (~t~+~~)~(~t~+~~)

\blert{\text{Step 2}}~~~The product of the Last terms is 18, so pq=18. There are three possibilities for p and q: 1 ~\text{and}~18,~~~ 2 ~\text{and}~9,~~~ \text{or}~~~ 3 ~\text{and}~6 We use the middle term of the trinomial to decide which possibility is correct.

\blert{\text{Step 3}}~~~The sum of Outside plus Inside is the middle term, 9t. We check each possibility to see which gives the correct middle term. \amp (t+1)(t+18) \amp \amp O+I = t+18t=19t \amp (t+2)(t+9) \amp \amp O+I = 2t+9t=11t \amp (t+3)(t+6) \amp \amp \blert{O+I = t+18t=19t} The last choice is correct, so the factorization is t^2+9t+18 = (t+3)(t+6)

\blert{\text{Exercise 1 }}~~~Factor each trinomial.
x^2+8x+15
y+2+14y+49
\blert{\text{CASE 2}}~~~ Negative linear coefficient: ~x^2-bx+c
If the coefficient of the linear term is negative and the constant term is positive, what are the signs of p and q?
\blert{\text{Example 2}}~~~Factor ~x^2-12x+20~ as a product of two binomials.

\blert{\text{Step 1}}~~~We look for a product of the form x^2-12x+20 = (x+p)(x+q) The numbers p and q must satisfy two conditions:
Their product, pq, is the Last term, and so must equal 20.
Their sum, p+q, equals -12 (because O+I = px+qx = -12x). These two conditions tell us that p and q must both be negative.
\blert{\text{Step 2}}~~~We list all the ways to factor 20 with negative factors: -1 ~\text{and}~-20,~~~ -2 ~\text{and}~-10,~~~ \text{or}~~~ -4 ~\text{and}~-5

\blert{\text{Step 3}}~~~We check each possibility to see which gives the correct middle term. \amp (x-1)(x-20) \amp \amp O+I = -20x-x=-21x \amp (x-2)(x-10) \amp \amp \blert{O+I = -10x-2x=-12x} \amp (x-4)(x-5) \amp \amp O+I = -4x-5x=-9x The second possibility is correct, so the factorization is x^2-12x+20 = (x-2)(x-10)

\blert{\text{Exercise 2}}~~~Factor each trinomial.
m^2-10m+24
m^2-11m+24
\blert{\text{CASE 3}}~~~ Negative constant term: ~x^2+bx-c~ or ~x^2-bx-c~
The linear term can be either positive or negative.
\blert{\text{Example 3}}~~~Factor ~x^2+2x-15~ as a product of two binomials.

\blert{\text{Step 1}}~~~We look for a factorization of the form x^2+2x-15 = (x+p)(x+q) The product pq of the two unknown numbers must be negative, -15. This means that p and q must have opposite signs, one positive and one negative. How do we decide which is positive and which is negative? We guess! If we make the wrong choice, we can easily fix it by switching the signs.

\blert{\text{Step 3}}~~~The second possibility gives a middle term of -2x. This is not quite correct, because the middle term we want is 2x. We fix this by switching the signs on the factors of 15: instead of using +3 and -5, we change to -3 and +5. You can check that the correct factorization is x^2+2x-15 = (x-3)(x+5)

\blert{\text{Exercise 3}}~~~Factor each trinomial.
t^2+8t-48
t^2-8t-48

subsubsection.title: Activity 3: Application
subsubsection.p:
The town of Amory lies due north of Chester, and Bristol lies due east of Chester. If you drive from Amory to Bristol by way of Chester, the distance is 17 miles, but if you take the back road directly from Amory to Bristol, you save 4 miles. You would like to know the distance from Bristol to Chester.
What is the unknown quantity? Call it x.
Make a sketch and label it with distances.
Write an equation about the variable.
Solve your equation.
How far is it from Bristol to Chester?
